Introduction



grouped and presented visually as bands connecting sub-areas. The
width of the band will be proportional to the number of desire lines
thus grouped. While this type of presentation distorts slightly indi-
vidual desire lines, it is helpful in comprehending desire line patterns
within a large area.)

Through Traffic: Traffic having neither origin nor destination within
a given area. As used in this report the term may relate to the
Baltimore metropolitan area, to the central business district, or to
residential neighborhoods. It is believed that the type of area re-
ferred to will, in each case, be clear from the context.

Traffic Generators: Areas within which there is a relatively high
concentration of points of traffic origin or destination.

While the Department of Planning and the Planning Commission
assume responsibility for the conclusions reached in this report, grateful
acknowledgment should be made to a number of individuals, firms, and
agencies for the invaluable assistance and advice which they have ren-
dered. A partial listing follows:

Department of Public Works
Urban Renewal and Housing Agency

Baltimore Regional Planning Council

Planning Council of the Greater Baltimore Committee
Mr. Alan M. Voorhees, Automotive Safety Foundation
Baltimore Gas & Electric Co.

Special acknowledgment should be made to Mr. Henry A. Barnes,
Commissioner of Transit and Traffic, and to Mr. James W. Booth, Jr.,
of his staff, and to Mr. Charles M. Upham, Jr., formerly of his staff. They
participated actively in much of the work and without their assistance this
report would not have been possible.

Within the Department of Planning the plans for the Harbor Route
were developed under the general supervision of Mr. John J. Lang,
Deputy Director for Planning Administration, and under the immediate
direction of Mr. Andrew J. Clarke, Jr., Principal City Planner, and Mr.
William Patschke, Senior City Planner.
